summary.p: Gast sends the commentary by [Wolfgang] Musculus on the first seven chapters of the Gospel of John. He will also send the continuation after its publication. - Gast did not see [Ludwig Lavater], the son of the [Zurich] mayor [Hans Rudolf Lavater], who did not deliver Bullinger's letter, and could not find him in the inns either. After three days, he learned that [Ludwig] had set off early in the morning for Strasbourg. - The arsonist [Duke Heinrich of Brunswick] commands a formidable army of allegedly 12,000 foot soldiers and 1,400 horsemen. He is burning down villages and towns everywhere and is trying to completely destroy [Landgrave Philipp of] Hesse. [Charles V] looks on. After the death of the Archbishop of Mainz [Albrecht of Brandenburg], the canons are disputing over the election [of a successor]. [Charles V] has something in mind with this bishopric. After the return of a [Basel] juror [...] from Strasbourg, more will soon be known.

div.p: Greetings in the Lord. I am sending you Musculus's commentary on the first seven chapters of the Gospel of John, and I will also send the rest if it is published, so that I do not appear ungrateful for the benefits you have shown me.

Furthermore, I want to inform you: I did not see the son of your mayor; he delivered your letters at dusk when I was not at home. The next day, I searched for him in the public inns, but I could not find the man. After three days, I learned that he had left early in the morning for Strasbourg.

The arsonist has a well-equipped army; they say he has 12,000 foot soldiers and 1,400 horsemen. He is burning down villages and small towns everywhere. He is trying to completely destroy Hesse. The Emperor is merely a spectator of this tragedy. The Archbishop of Mainz has died, and the canons are disputing among themselves about electing a bishop. The Emperor is planning something with this bishopric. If I hear anything more certain, I will write, and soon we will have the whole business of this matter when our tribune of the people returns from Strasbourg.
Farewell in the Lord. Basel, October 17, 1545. Yours, Gastius, in haste.
To the distinguished theologian, Heinrich Bullinger, most vigilant pastor of the Church of Zurich, his dearest brother. Zurich.
